questions.question: ........................... I ask you something?
questions.description: Both can and could are possible here. Could is more polite than can.

questions.question: She said I ............................ come as often as I liked.
questions.description: When the main clause is in the past tense, we need a past tense in the subordinate clause as well.

questions.question: Jack ................................. not go to work yesterday because he was ill.
questions.description: Could is the past tense form of can. Here the time expression yesterday clearly indicates that we are referring to the past.

questions.question: He ............................. borrow my car, if she asked.
questions.description: In conditional clauses, if the verb in the if-clause is in the past tense, we use could / would / might + infinitive in the main clause.

questions.question: I .................................... her, if I had wanted to.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the past perfect tense, we use would / could have + past participle in the main clause.

questions.question: .......................... you lend me some pounds until tomorrow?
questions.description: Both can and could are possible here.

questions.question: When I was a child, I ............................ play whenever I wanted to.
'Where is John?' He .......................... be in the garden.
questions.description: Can is not used in affirmative sentences to talk about logical possibility.

questions.question: It was a place where anything .......................... happen.
questions.description: We use could here because the main clause is in the past tense.

questions.question: I ............................ not understand anything she said.
questions.description: We use could here because the verb in the other clause is in the past tense.

questions.question: You ............................ get a better job if you speak English.
questions.description: When the verb in the if-clause is in the present tense, we use will / can + infinitive in the main clause

questions.question: War ............................ break out any day.
questions.description: Can and could are possible here could shows weak possibility.
